div.head: Startling incidents
div.p: The Garret—The Supper—The Passage—The Staircase—The Murder— The Poisoning—the————The Denouement.

list.item: Snooks.—Shabby genteel modern dress—check trousers—white hat. Dabbs.—Picturesque melodramatic ruffian's dress of modern style. Pilfer.—Fancy sporting suit—very shabby. Miss Chubb.—Ordinary chambermaid's dress.

div.p: The Author of this little quiz upon the extravagances of the transpontine melodrama, is well aware how much he was indebted for its favourable reception to the talent displayed by the original performers who figured in the cast. The piece was one of his earliest contributions to the stage, and enjoyed the advantages of the scenic illusions provided by Mr. William Beverly, the genial humour of Mr. George Wild, the excellent acting of Mr. William Searle, and the admirable artistic, performance of Mr. James Rogers, who ingeniously expanded a small part into a very important one. It is with pleasure that he thus gratefully acknowledges their valuable assistance, and thanks them for the success which the farce attained on the boards of the Old Olympic Theatre.

div.head: SCENE FIRST.
div.stage: —A Garret. Practicable window in flat, backed by tiles, with curtain drawn—bed, table, two chairs— carpet, fender—fireplace, L.—door, R.—wash stand, jug, basin —small cupboard in flat, with plate, knife and fork, mustard pot, bottle, and teacup in—two pork chops at the fire—coat over chair, white hat on nail—pipes and screw of tobacco on shelf—broken bit of looking glass—old candlestick and candle lighted—pen, ink, and newspapers, with letters manifold, &c.
Septimus Snooks discovered at table writing by the light of a small candle.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p:
Fourteen lines, one and ninepence. Come, there's a breakfast for some day next week, at all events! Let me see how it reads. “Singular and Remarkable Accident. Yesterday afternoon, between the hours of one and six, as a gentleman, named Brown.” Brown! Thank goodness there are plenty of Browns! “was proceeding in his chaise along Oxford Street—” Capital street that—there's no knowing at which end things do occur! “the off wheel came, horrible to relate, against the birch broom of the street sweeper opposite, and such was the violence of the concussion, that the broom was immediately snapped in two, and the handle flying upwards, knocked the unfortunate gentleman off his seat into the window of a china shop next door—at the same instant, the horse and chaise took fright, in consequence of a little boy mischievously making faces, and dashed off at a rapid speed into the kitchen of—Smith, Esq., to the astonishment of the cook, who was frying pancakes at the time, and whose alarm may be much better conceived than described. The horse and chaise were
extricated with great difficulty, and Mr. Brown resumed him journey with only the loss of his temper. The making-face nuisance we strongly recommend the police to look after.” So there's the result of my penny-a-lining for to-night, and now to send this romantic novel, in one paragraph, to the morning newspapers—I can't go myself for certain very peculiar reasons, and— (knock at door, R. 3 E.) That's somebody at the door. Now I shouldn't wonder if it is that persevering landlady of mine, who has the audacity to want some money! Come in!
sp.stage: Enter Miss Chubb, cautiously, L. D.

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: Are you there, Mr. Snooks?

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Oh, it's you, my dear. Yes, I am here, and I wish I wasn't—you come, I believe, for your little account?

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: Why, my mother—

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Ah, I know. Dutiful daughter—and couldn't refuse—wished to avoid the disagreeable task—obliged to undertake it! You look more pretty to-night than ever, Miss Chubb.

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: Thankye, sir—but if you'd be pleased to settle—

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: So I do settle. I settle my affections upon you, and isn't that sufficient?

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: Why, sir, the bill has been so long standing—

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: That you want it re-seated, eh? But if you will wait until to-morrow—

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: My mother, Mr. Snooks, said I was not to go till a was properly balanced, and therefore, I can't wait.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Then tell your mother Mr. Snooks says it can't be properly balanced without waits.

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: But this week's rent is also due, Mr. Snooks.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: I know it is—and being due it becomes nothing for dew is vapour, and vapour in air, and air is nothing—at least that air. However, here is that which will produce money. (takes paper from table) Send these round to the newspapers as directed, for me, and a grateful heart—

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Snooks, I can refuse you nothing—you will pay us to-morrow?

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: To be sure I will. Good night, Miss Chubb.

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: Good night, Mr. Snooks!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Fare thee well, and if for ever—

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: Oh, what a nice young man he is to be sure!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p:
Making love's the cheapest thing, after all! Now for supper! Two pork chops, the remainder of to-day's dinner. Indigestible, very—but tempting exceedingly. If there is one
thing I have a partiality for more than another, it is a pork chop. One good turn deserves another.
Talking of turns, what turns, I've had to be sure! what a life I've led!

Now, then, to see about supper, and to lay the cloth. (lays newspaper on table) There, that's what I call blending the ornamental with the useful! I can read and inwardly digest together. (goes to cupboard, fetches plate, knife, fork, teacup, and bottle—gets chops) I have an appetite for two, but only a knife and fork for one, though no friend will pop into supper I expect, and as the old joke says, “If these chops are not ready, I know those that are.” (eating) Done to a nicety! rather fat, but if they were fat, fair, and forty, my “great revenge has stomach for them all.” What shifts we literary men are obliged to put up with sometimes! There am I—generalissimo of inquests, and purveyor-general of accidents in ordinary to the whole of the newspaper press, compelled to reside in this classical abode, where they do say, one Dabbs, a burglar, was taken—capital chops these! By the way, my last robbery turned out very productive! fourteen shillings is no bad week! I must have a try at a murder next. Poor Dabbs! I wonder what became of him? I dare say the account of his capture made two columns at the least. I'll drink his health. (pours from bottle into teacup) Small beer two days old. (drinks) I suppose they call this small beer because you can't drink a large quantity of it. Well, I must do the honours of the table, at all events. Mr. Snooks, permit me to have the honour of drinking your good health. Thank you, sir—the same to you. There—I wonder what sort of night it is? (draws aside curtain, discovering tiles by moonlight) Poor Dabbs! I should like to know whether his ghost walks on the housetops! (a guitar and voice heard outside) Hark! there's a ballad singer in the court! Well, I'm amazingly fond of music, so I shall patronise native talent. There, old girl, it's the last. (throws penny) And, now then to enjoy my pipe, and listen to hers at the same time. (fetches pipe and screw off mantelpiece) Not much of the weed left, I declare. Well, it certainly can't be an ill weed, for it don't grow apace. (Female sings a verse of “Lovely Night”) How sleepy that small beer makes one! Poor Dabbs! I certainly must get up a murder—they pay best! Miss Chubb—those pork chops—robbery—Dabbs, the housebreaker—oh!
sp.stage: (Music— gradually dozes off to sleep—knocks candle down)

div.head: SCENE SECOND.
div.stage: Enter Miss Chubbs, with bed candle.

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p:
Bless my heart, how late it is getting to be sure!
I must go to the arms of Morpheus, as Mr. Snooks says. By the way, that Mr. Snooks is a very nice young man. I don't see why mother should be so cross with him, though he does owe five weeks' rent—four-and-sixpence a week, and find his own blacking brushes. When a single young man lodger occupies a place in your heart, though, it's high time to give him notice to quit! Well, I suppose I must get to bed, though I dare say I shall not close my eyes for dreaming about Mr. Septimus Snooks. Oh, dear! love is something like the pork chops Mr. Snooks talked about—very nice at the time, but very apt to keep you awake o' nights.

div.head: SCENE THIRD.
div.stage: —Garret, as before. Fire out—moon gone down—rain—thunder.
Dabbs appears at back, making his way along the tiles—enters through window with bag, dark lantern, &c.—Music at the opening of scene.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: So far 'tis fortunate. The thirsty gang of peelers, who would fain my carcass have, are baulked in their career, and I am in safety. This my swag, for which I've robbed a shopkeeper, who robbed the world in turn, will make me rich, and bear me to a land far from the taxed and taxing soil of Britain. (Snooks snores) Ah, an intruder! Let me reconnoitre. (Music —He surveys, with his lantern, the apartment, and at last discovers Snooks) Ah, a stranger! (pulls Snooks to the front of the stage) How came you here?

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: You pulled me!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: You are a traitor!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: No, I'm a penny-a-liner!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Ah, you know then—

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: I do!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: And you are—

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Whilst your name is—

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Snooks.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Enough—rise!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: You deal in robberies?

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Yes—I make them.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Did you ever commit a murder?

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: No, but I mean to.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: On what?

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Paper.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Psha! you behold this bag?

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Take it!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: You have received stolen goods. My name is Dabbs —Darkeye Dabbs—Dabbs the Housebreaker. Ha, ha! do you tremble at the sound?

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Not a bit of it!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: You have good spirits!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: It has dwindled to small beer lately.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Will you join me?

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Yes, as your historian. You shall commit robberies, and I'll write them. I will give you a last dying speech and confession with pleasure.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: You may stand yourself in need. Suppose I split!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Then you might keep your half.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: True; but you must be fatigued, and I have a tale to tell. Let us be seated.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: You'll excuse my furniture. I'm not accustomed to receive company.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Listen—

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: I will!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Fourteen years ago I was a housebreaker.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: That was a go!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: A regular housebreaker—a professor of the science of crib cracking, on the same plan as that pursued by the late Mr. John Sheppard!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: You don't say so!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Whilst following my professional avocations, I was a tenant occupying this very room. I at last left for the army!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: I see—you were a left-tenant.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: I picked pockets at the Horse Guards!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: And became yourself one of the blackguards; but proceed!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: One night, whilst here, I was asked for my rent.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Insolent audacity!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: It was an insult that I never forgave—day and night I brooded over it, and swore to be revenged. Time flew past, and I was invited one morning to visit the Old Bailey, on account of a little legal affair at which my presence was desired. As I was about to leave, a gentleman begged me to go abroad at the expense of the Government, to aid in the colonisation of Botany Bay.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: And you—

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Consented. I was always patriotic, even in my prejudices. So I remained fourteen long years engaged in advancing the mercantile interest of that country. Still I forgot not the insult, and here I am, returned for the purpose of accomplishing the long cherished object of my thoughts— revenge!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Wonderful being! and the purport of your visit this night?

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Is to fulfil my vow, and gratify my revenge! She sleeps in the second floor. From that slumber she must never— (three taps on the tiles) Hark!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Did you hear anything knock?

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: It is the signal—my comrade has arrived.
sp.stage: Music.—Phil slides down the tiles and enters through window.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Well, this gentleman seems to be making himself quite at home.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Allow me the pleasure of introducing a friend—this is Mr.—

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Snooks!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Mr. Snooks! and this my comrade, Phil Pilfer, better known to the world as Paddington Phil. Hope you may be better acquainted.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Your servant, sir—and the public's to command.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Is this one of the profession? (Dabbs nods mysteriously) I see how it is! this will be quite a house of call for them before long. What a situation for a gentleman connected with the press.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Now, then, to business. Is all prepared?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: All!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: One would imagine they were going to sit down to supper, instead of its being the committal of—

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Who talks of a committal?

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Why, you surely wouldn't—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But we have sworn—

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Several times!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Don't doubt it!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: The hour has arrived. To the second floor! Lead on—my victim waits me. Follow!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: I will—to watch the result. It may end in—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Murder!
sp.stage: Puts lantern up to Snooks's face. Music.—Exeunt at door —tableau formed.

div.head: SCENE FOURTH.
div.stage: Music continued—stage dark. Snooks, Phil, and Dabbs cross the stage L. and exit, R. Enter Miss Chubb, L.

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: Disturbed by the sound of footsteps, I have hastened hither, and if that light misled me not, saw three strangers cross the landing. What can this mean? Surely some vile plot is being carried on—the house entered by thieves, perhaps. Should Snooks be one—but oh no! the thought is unworthy of him. Ah, the light proceeds—stops—goes on —no—it pauses at the staircase; and now the extinguisher is popped upon it—a few more paces, and I can discern their object—gently, gently—let me observe.

div.head: SCENE FIFTH.
div.stage: —The Staircase to lower apartment. Windows over the stairs practicable, R.
Dabbs, Snooks, and Phil discovered on stairs—they descend. Picture.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: So! we are on the second landing. This is the most singular affair in which I was ever engaged. Can't you put it off, to oblige me?

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Psha! you grow chicken-hearted. Drink! (producing bottle) It's brandy! hark!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Phoo! it's only the cats!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: I heard mysterious sounds—the very tiles seem to start from the roof!

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: That is the voice of Snooks! can he be a robber?

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Come, I'm in no hurry. (takes cups from bag) I'll give you a toast, and you give us a song.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Consider the neighbours!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Phoo! what have we to do with them. Let's enjoy ourselves!

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: Some dreadful deed is about to be committed. Could I but gain yonder cupboard—there is laudanum in it, and perhaps—
sp.stage: (she descends, goes to cupboard, and gets the phial—Dabbs has poured out the brandy into cup, and holds it up, R. looking at Snooks—Miss Chubb pours the contents of phial into the cup.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Now, then, here's to Jerry—

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Psha!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: No, not Shaw, but Jerry Abershaw!

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: That will frustrate their murderous design, at least.
sp.stage: (Dabbs gives Snooks the cup, who drinks)

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Here's to Jerry Abershaw!

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: He has taken the poisoned goblet by mistake. All is lost!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Here's to Jerry Abershaw, and our enterprise!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: To our enterprise!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Now then, to complete my design! As you (crosses to Phil) were once an omnibus conductor behind, before, go in front. Here, take this lantern, and remember to strike home!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: This seems a striking situation altogether.
sp.stage: Music.—Dabbs and Phil, in melodramatic action, signify that they are about to commit murder, telling Snooks to follow, and exeunt.

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: Not a moment is to be lost. Fly, dear Snooks, if you value my love or your own life. You are poisoned, and by me! The shaft which I aimed at another, has recoiled upon your own head.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Poisoned! nonsense! yet now I think again, my brain is in a whirling world—the floor is walking up to the ceiling, and the walls are playing at leapfrog. Oh, fatal hour of ours, to be poisoned, and by you, Miss Chubb. Hark! know you that in yonder chamber a dreadful deed is being performed.

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: Think not of me—the room is empty—we have removed down stairs.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Down stairs! parlours be praised! but those dreadful men—

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: One of them is poisoned, too. But run to the doctor's.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: And leave you here! never!

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: Hark! they return! behind this staircase we may observe their movements.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: True, we must take steps to conceal ourselves.

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Confusion! our prey has escaped. Follow to the garret—to the garret!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
I can go no further—thoughts of the time when I was
a happy cad to a Paddington 'bus comes rushing o'er my mind! My brain wanders! “Bank! city! bank!” I'm poisoned! I feel upon my temples an—“Elephant and Castle!” Look! see that shadowy form in the pepper and salt unmentionables! I know you well—it's a bad sixpence. Ah! ha, ha, ha!

“Going down, sir?” “Is that an umbrella that I see before me! with its hook turned towards this way?” It is—ah! I see thee and yet I have thee not! Come, let me clutch thee! “Hold hard, Bill!” “This way, sir—Baker Street! Yorkshire Sting— oh! Full inside! Drive on! (Music—Dies)

div.stage: Enter Dabbs, and carries Phil off, L.—Miss Chubb and Snooks appear, R.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: It will be my turn next—I feel I'm on the same road—for— Re-enter Dabbs, l. Hold! you and I have yet accounts to reckon—so pay me now, for I will count blows upon that head till one of our two bodies prove it's settled!

sp.speaker: Dabbs.
sp.p: Agreed! one dead, another shall be so.
I've had one breeze, and do not fear your blow.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Then, traitor, turn, and Snooks will bravely fight,
Till Darkeye Dabbs despairing dies downright.

div.stage: (Music—they struggle—Dabbs throws Snooks off, who falls —Dabbs falls over him, and leaves the dagger stuck in the stage—Miss Chubb rushes down stage, obtains it—Dabbs retreats up stairs—Snooks follows—they struggle—Snooks throws Dabbs out of window—Miss Chubb kneels at bottom of stairs.—Tableau.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: All is over—the poison works! the murders are done! the housebreaker is thrown over, and I'm overthrown! Oh, Chubb! Chubb! heroic girl! I have long had my eye upon you, and now you'll be in time to see me hook it! Farewell! a long farewell to all my greatness. I shall have an inquest held upon me—on me, who have gone in quest of so many myself! In half-an-hour the laudanum will have done its work—the remaining time I will employ to my own profit. I'll go to my garret and write the account of my own death for the morning papers—I go, and it is done—there will be a good report of my tragical ending, at all events. The pen—the ink—the paper! What ho! oh!

sp.speaker: Miss Chubb.
sp.p: Mr. Snooks! Mr. Snooks! What can have possibly happened to him?

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Who calls on Snooks?

sp.speaker: Miss Chubb.
sp.p: Why, do you know what time it is? It's past ten! and here's a letter been waiting for you this hour and more!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: A letter! Why, surely—where am I? can I have been dreaming all this while? It must be so. I'll see if she knows anything about it! (opens door) Enter Miss Chubb, with letter. Why, bless my heart, Miss Chubb, you don't look as if you'd been up all night!

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: La! why should I? You've been dreaming I am afraid, Mr. Snooks.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Dreaming! Oh, I see how it is! those cursed pork chops—fit of indigestion, caused the nightmare, and having my brain bewildered with murders and robberies during the day, I've been dreaming about robbers all night!

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: And so you've really had the nightmare through eating pork chops!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Yes; rather porkuliar, isn't it? But this letter! (takes it) Who can it be from? I haven't had a letter this twelvemonth. (reads) “Dear Septimus,—Uncle Bob has remembered you in his will, and left you an annuity of fifty pounds a-year, with his pork shop in the Borough. Can't write more, as the post is just leaving. Your affectionate cousin, Angelica Snooks.” Fifty pounds a year and a pork shop in the Borough! I'm a made man! Your mother's rent shall be paid, and you shall be Mrs. Snooks!

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: La, Septimus, you don't say so!

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: It's a bargain! I'm so overjoyed that even the nightmare is forgotten, so we'll invite our friends, here, to come another night.

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: At nine o'clock, to supper.

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: But how to serve this novel dish of fun?
Perhaps some may think our Pork Chops over done!

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: To these kind friends you should refer the questions,
And hope our jest—

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: Agreed; and though our dish is only plain—

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: We trust you'll cut—

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: As for your sanction here, the actor stops,

sp.speaker: Miss C.
sp.p: And stakes his happiness—

sp.speaker: Snooks.
sp.p: On these Pork Chops.
